pullRequest.body:
+ `equiv_iff_eq_of_Z_eq`: if a point has two representations in Jacobian coordinates with the same, nonzero Z-coordinate, then the two representations are equal.

+ `nonsingular_iff_of_Z_ne_zero`: a lemma deleted in an earlier PR for no reason, now restored.

+ `addXYZ_self`: if the addition (not doubling) formula is applied to a point representative and itself, the result is (0,0,0).

+ `addXYZ_neg`: the addition formula applied to a point representative and its negation yields a representative of the point at infinity.

+ two trivial lemmas `fromAffine_ne_zero` and `comp_fin3`.

+ a series of `map` lemmas showing the addition and doubling formulas in Jacobian coordinates commute with ring homomorphisms.

---

GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9679258468/job/26704846048)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9679258468/job/26704846637)
LGTM otherwise. I will likely move a few things around when I split the file, so I won't bother you further with minor golfs or rearrangements.
The rest looks good but I am not an expert
Thanks! Here are some preliminary suggestions. I will look into the code later.
Some further comments.
LGTM otherwise. I will likely move a few things around when I split the file, so I won't bother you further with minor golfs or rearrangements.

Can you either
* remove this lemma in favour of lemmas about `vecCons` and `vecEmpty`
* make this lemma `private`

It's primarily used in a different file (`ZSMul.lean`) so I don't think it can be made private ...? We have four similar convenience lemmas starting from [WeierstrassCurve.Jacobian.fin3_def](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/AlgebraicGeometry/EllipticCurve/Jacobian.html#WeierstrassCurve.Jacobian.fin3_def) and I don't think they're outrageous ... It's convenient to do a single controlled rewrite, even if `simp` does it all.
Yeah, I think this is sensible just for our purposes, as long we hide them in the `Jacobian` namespace.

I would move this to right below `fin3_def` or `smul_fin3`, but it's not a huge deal. I will eventually split this file into smaller files and relocate a lot of things, so I might as well do that then.
Why is my first option not viable?

What are we supposed to do with the first option? It does seem that `comp_vecCons` and `comp_vecEmpty` are missing, but IMO that should be another PR, because I do want `comp_fin3` for precise rewrite using a single lemma, and its proofs can't be made shorter with the `comp_vecCons/Empty` lemmas.

(Lemmas like [WeierstrassCurve.Jacobian.smul_fin3](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/AlgebraicGeometry/EllipticCurve/Jacobian.html#WeierstrassCurve.Jacobian.smul_fin3) can't be generalized to arbitrary vectors since different coordinate has different weighting (exponent).)
@eric-wieser, do you think the above lemmas are good candidates for a reflection approach?
This lemma already exists in the reflection library

```suggestion
  linear_combination -2 * P z ^ 2 * (equation_iff _).mp hP
```
I changed this because `` and `` are not Lean code.

I don't think we have to use Lean code in docstrings, and I very much prefer docstrings readable in both the editor and the online docs, so I sometimes enclose readable pseudocode rather than actual Lean code in backquotes. However I agree in this case it's probably better to use actual Lean code since you're explain a technical Lean issue, but my version could also be made into actual code by [adding an import](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/superscript.20parser/near/365151927).
Wow!
Surely `simp only` still works?

Yeah, but `simp_rw` is shorter and allows you to see intermediate goal states, which is why I prefer it. I never tested if there are noticeable performance differences compared to `simp only`, and these two proofs are possibly too trivial for `simp_rw` to be beneficial?
Makes sense, but I'm too used to `simp only`. One of these days I'll change all my `simp only` into `simp_rw`'s.

I think the direction should be `f (addZ P Q) = addZ (f  P) (f  Q)` based on `map` lemmas throughout mathlib, and I don't think you should make this `simp` in that case. Similarly for the other lemmas below this.
This is a good point; it seems I'm only using `map_addXYZ` and `map_dblXYZ` in the reverse direction, so it's probably good to reverse the direction and keep the `@[simp]`.

In https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13846/commits/1a5e80ac9c8729d761e69b44ab137535bb622b20 I switched the direction of the `map` lemmas except for those about `polynomial(X,Y,Z)`. Now `map_polynomial(X,Y,Z)` has `WeierstrassCurve.map` on LHS, in contrast to the other `map` lemmas, but they agree with the affine lemmas, and since they are not marked `@[simp]` now I think it's okay. I think their names are acceptable, since there are plenty of lemmas following this naming convention like [Prod.map_injective](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Prod/Basic.html#Prod.map_injective).

Hmm should I really have switched the directions? Now these `simp` lemmas are contrary to the `simp` direction of [WeierstrassCurve.map_a](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/AlgebraicGeometry/EllipticCurve/Weierstrass.html#WeierstrassCurve.map_a%E2%82%81) etc.
This is why I'm hesitant on which direction simp should be. I don't know if the simp direction of `map_a*` is correct.
Well, those map_a* are generated by @[simps] so it would be hard to argue the direction or the name isn't correct. I think I'll revert the commit ...

```suggestion
  simp only [Units.smul_def, (mul_cancel_right_mem_nonZeroDivisors mem).mp hz, one_smul]
```

I use `hQz` for `Q z \ne 0` exclusively everywhere:
```suggestion
lemma equiv_iff_eq_of_Z_eq [NoZeroDivisors R] {P Q : Fin 3  R} (hz : P z = Q z) (hQz : Q z  0) :
    P  Q  P = Q :=
  equiv_iff_eq_of_Z_eq' hz (mem_nonZeroDivisors_of_ne_zero hQz)
```

```suggestion
`P = u  Q`. However, `u  Q` is not syntactically equal to `![u * Q x, u * Q y, u * Q z]`, so the
lemmas `smul_fin3` and `smul_fin3_ext` can be used to convert between the two forms.
```
I like to reserve some empty spaces for occasional edits ... Do you have some automation for greedy line filling?
Not really, it's just my habit to do it manually.
Can you remind me where you need this?

No I don't need this, but I think it's an interesting result, and it can be generalized to arbitrary comm. rings assuming `P z` is not a zero divisor, because in analogy to [`polynomial_relation`](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/1f26889564894e26ba35676b550f5283071256da/Mathlib/AlgebraicGeometry/EllipticCurve/Projective.lean#L214-L216) in the projective API, here we have
```
6 * eval P W.polynomial = 2 * P x * eval P W.polynomialX + 3 * P y * eval P W.polynomialY + P z * eval P W.polynomialZ
```
due to weighted homogeneity, which you use with `P z = 1` in `nonsingular_some`.
Ah sure, can you generalise it to that context then, if it's not too difficult?

I have it ready [here](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/compare/Euler_homogeneous...EllCurve/Jacobian_homogeneous?expand=1#diff-fbad8e13903b8830a3972d6559954956a0838eb9c5729196639611aa39e181b6) but I prefer to merge this first. It's another +40 -14 on top of this.

By the way I think a more meaningful definition of `Nonsingular` is that the three derivatives generate the unit ideal. In order to get rid of the third derivative, the sufficient condition is `IsUnit (P z)` rather than `P z  R`. I'm not sure whether either of these two forms of the lemma will ever be used though.

Since we now have `nonsingular_iff_of_Z_ne_zero`, we can add back `nonsingular_iff_of_Y_eq_negY`:
```
lemma nonsingular_iff_of_Y_eq_negY {P : Fin 3  F} (hPz : P z  0) (hy : P y = W.negY P) :
    W.Nonsingular P  W.Equation P  eval P W.polynomialX  0 := by
  rw [nonsingular_iff_of_Z_ne_zero hPz, show eval P W.polynomialY = P y - W.negY P by
      rw [negY, eval_polynomialY]; ring1, hy, sub_self, ne_self_iff_false, or_false]
```
Presumably we add this right after `Y_eq_negY_of_Y_eq`. Now we can golf this:
```suggestion
lemma dblU_ne_zero_of_Y_eq {P Q : Fin 3  F} (hP : W.Nonsingular P) (hPz : P z  0) (hQz : Q z  0)
    (hx : P x * Q z ^ 2 = Q x * P z ^ 2) (hy : P y * Q z ^ 3 = Q y * P z ^ 3)
    (hy' : P y * Q z ^ 3 = W.negY Q * P z ^ 3) : W.dblU P  0 :=
  ((nonsingular_iff_of_Y_eq_negY hPz <| Y_eq_negY_of_Y_eq hQz hx hy hy').mp hP).right
```
Applied the change.

A legal one-liner:
```suggestion
  linear_combination (norm := (rw [addX]; ring1)) -2 * P z ^ 2 * (equation_iff _).mp hP
```
Move `addZ_self` to right below the definition of `addZ`, and the same goes for `addX_self`, `negAddY_self`, `addY_self`, and `addXYZ_self` to their respective locations.

```suggestion
  erw [addY, addX_self hP, negAddY_self, addZ_self, negY_of_Z_eq_zero rfl, neg_zero]
```

```suggestion
    * (equation_iff _).mp hP
```

I don't know how much you need this lemma written out explicitly, because this is just:
```suggestion
  addZ_of_X_eq rfl
```
I'd still include it for completeness/consistency even though it can be inlined :)
If you're OK with working with fields, you can re-use `addX_of_X_eq` with a lot more assumptions, but the proof won't be shorter than this... I'm guessing we don't want this.

`addXYZ_neg` is used [here](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/3d6da3dc779ad9a87bb94300bdc06f793e122d4e/Mathlib/AlgebraicGeometry/EllipticCurve/DivisionPolynomial/ZSMul.lean#L458-L461) where I'm indeed working in the universal field, but I think it's cool that it holds in arbitrary comm. rings.

This reduces the need for `simp` but is two lines:
```suggestion
  rw [addY, addX_neg hP, negAddY_neg hP, negY_of_Z_eq_zero addZ_neg]
  rfl
```
I'd just squeeze it into one line :)

No need for `simp`:
```suggestion
  erw [addXYZ, addX_neg hP, addY_neg hP, addZ_neg, smul_fin3, neg_sq, mul_one,
    Odd.neg_pow <| by decide, mul_one, mul_zero]
```
Now that we have this, can you also add the analogous statement `add_neg` after `add_of_X_ne`?

I don't think you can come up with a nice statement of `add_neg` since it may be the case that `P  W'.neg P` so that `dblXYZ` would apply instead, but `dblXYZ` takes a single point rather than two so it won't account for the unit `u` such that `W'.neg P = u  P`.

```suggestion
  obtain u, eq := Quotient.eq.mp <| (Point.ext_iff ..).mp h0
```
Once we have the equivalence between affine and Jacobian coordinates, this follows from the fact that `.some` isn't `0`, but I guess you want this for non-trivial rings too?
Yeah, no harm to have a more general version around ...
Move this to below `comp_fin3` too? Since this is a general fact about `Fin 3`s.
This does need `f` to be a ring homomorphism, so I think it does fit here, unlike `comp_fin3`.
This is `FinVec.map_eq`
Thanks! It seems it can't be directly used to rewrite to the desired form, or to replace `comp_fin3` in a `simp` call, so I just changed the proof of `comp_fin3` to use it.

Untested:
```suggestion
  (FinVec.map_eq ..).symm
```
Since we already have `FinVec.map_eq`, do we still need `comp_fin3`? Otherwise, should this be `comp_fin3_ext`, and does it make sense to have an analogous `comp_fin3` for `P : Fin 3 -> R`?
As I [commented](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13846#discussion_r1643750769), it can't be used to rewrite to the desired form directly.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(EllipticCurve): lemmas in Jacobian coordinates
